en.value: Do you have a big family?
Talking more about our family and other relatives - Making comparisons and expressing possession
How do you know each other?
Let's take a look at some words that are useful when talking about how we are related to different people.
Read and listen to the word and the key phrase.
I have one uncle on my dad's side.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
My cousin is my aunt's son.
I don't see my cousin often, as she lives in Mexico.
My cousin is 12, but he looks much younger.
The word "cousin" is gender neutral in English, meaning that we use it to refer to both a cousin that is female and a cousin that is male.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
We generally say "close family" to mean that a family is close and well-connected, but it can also mean that someone is a central member of the family.
Match the female and male equivalents.
Talking of having a close family, we often call members of our family by more affectionate names. Generally, these words end in a "y". Have a look at the examples below.
To recap, here are the words we have just looked at:
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Joseph has just met Maria's family for the first time.
Wow. You have such a big family!
I know. Did you meet my [k]aunty[/k]?
I think so. That's Helena's [k]mum[/k], right?
No, that's my [k]cousin[/k]! Linda's my aunty.
Oh! She's nice. Is Keira her [k]daughter[/k]?
No! Keira's my [k]sister[/k]. And then Polly's my [k]niece[/k].
Oh, I see. Your [k]niece[/k] is really cute. Okay, I think I've got it!
Julia is Liem's aunt, so Liem is her...
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Select the words in the correct order.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Emma's uncle lives in New York.
Emma's visiting her aunt in Paris.
Emma's cousin lives with her uncle.
My [k]uncle lives[/k] in Australia, so we don't see him very often.
Who do you have in your family? Write or record your response.
I have two aunts, an uncle and two nephews...

So far, we've mainly compared the qualities of people / objects in sentences like "Michael is taller than Maria." or "I find Physics more interesting than Biology." In this unit, we are going to look at comparing the quantity of people / objects. Take a look at the examples below.
There are more restaurants than bars in my town.
This sentence is comparing quantities of different things.
You probably recognise the structure more ... than .... We use it for these kinds of comparisons too. Have a look at the examples below.
There are more women than men in my company.
I watch more TV series than films.
I drink more coffee than tea.
Select the comparative word which is the opposite of "more".
I have less free time this weekend than next weekend.
He has fewer clothes than his brother.
Remember that we use "less" with nouns that we can't count, "fewer" with nouns that we can count, and "more" with both!
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Even some native speakers get mixed up between "less" and "fewer". Watch out for common mistakes like this:
There are less men than women in my company.
There are fewer men than women in my company.
There are [k]f[/k][k]e[/k][k]w[/k][k]e[/k][k]r[/k] women than men in my class.
I work [k]fewer[/k] hours than you do.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Fill the gap with the opposite of "more".
I have [k]fewer[/k] exams this year [k]than[/k] last year.
She has [k]more[/k] books than I do.
Fill the gap with the opposite of "fewer".
Grammar: Possessive form of the noun

We already learned how to say that something belongs to somebody by using possessive adjectives (my, his, her, etc). Now let's look at how we express possession between one thing / person and another. To do this we use a special form of the noun. Have a look at how we form it below.
It was my cousin's birthday yesterday.
For plural nouns ending in "s", we simply add an apostrophe after the "s", like this:
Here are some possessive forms of plural nouns that do not end in "s". Can you see the difference between these and the ones above?
To make a possessive form, we simply add an apostrophe to the end of the word above.
You can find [k]children's[/k] books on the 4th floor.

If the singular form of a noun ends in "-y", we still form the possessive by simply adding 's. We don't change the "-y" to "-ie" like we do in the plural form of the noun. Have a look at the examples below.
This means "the flags of the countries".
This means "the flag of the country".
We also use the possessive form of a noun to refer to shops, restaurants, churches and colleges, using the name or job title of the owner.
I have an appointment at the dentist's at 9 a.m. (dentist's practice)
Shall we meet at Johnny's for lunch? (a restaurant)
Shall we meet at Johnny's for lunch?
I have an appointment at the dentist's at 9 a.m.
I have an appointment at the [k]dentist's[/k] at 9 a.m.
At James's uncle's and aunt's house.
No way... that's [k]Caroline's[/k] new car?! For goodness' sake. She's only 16!
Whose car are Magda and James talking about?
Select the correct form of the noun.
It's my neph[k]e[/k][k]w[/k][k]'[/k][k]s[/k] birthday this weekend.
In fact, it's Jam[k]e[/k][k]s[/k][k]'[/k][k]s[/k] new girlfriend.
Fill in the gap using the image.
Excuse me, could you tell me where the [k]ladies'|girls'[/k] room is?
I have an appointment at the [k]doctor's[/k] at 11 am.
